resources.string:
Views of satellites are drastically different as you move from town to town. 
You can turn on GPS tracking to follow Your Location from neighbourhood to neighbourhood 
OR you can keep GPS off to save on battery life. 
 
If you decide to change this Setting, tap on the GPS button 
or go to the General tab and change Track GPS.
You have updated your location. \nWould you like to download the forecast, now?
I am trying to update your location. \nCancel that and continue with app, now?
You have no locations in your library. \nYou still need to download the forecast.
You have no locations in your library. \nGo to Settings, and in the General tab, change the name of the Observatory location name to something other than Your Location. \nThen, download the forecast.
Share the forecast on social media
When you update weather and events, use GPS to find Your Location. \nTo keep track of your favourite observation points, update the Observatory Location Name.
Fetch a known location when you are in the neighbourhood.
Notify when a significant meteor shower is peaking
Display asterisk on main screen if the Moon is currently above the horizon, day or night
Display asterisk on main screen if any planets will be visible in the night sky
Display asterisk on main screen if any planets or the Moon will be near a bright star or planet in the night sky
Alert when it gets closer than
Notify when a comet is visible
Notify when the aurora will be visible, based on location, weather, and lighting conditions
Notify when satellites are about to pass overhead, based on location and weather
Display asterisk on main screen if any of your favourite constellations will be visible in the night sky
Notify when a variable star will be nearing maximum or minimum in the night sky
Notify when a solar or lunar eclipse will occur
Constellations north of 30° latitude on the celestial sphere
Constellations between 30° N and 30° S on the celestial sphere
Constellations south of 30° latitude on the celestial sphere
Mother of Andromeda, the Queen on her throne

string-array.name: glossary_definitions
string-array.item: The line on the celestial sphere precisely followed by the Sun, and approximately followed by the Moon and planets. It passes through the twelve signs of the zodiac.
The set of constellations on the ecliptic used in Eastern and Hindu astrology, beginning with Aquarius.
The set of equally spaced regions on the ecliptic used in Western astrology, beginning with Aries.

resources.string: This will launch an app by another author who is solely responsible for its content.
Open the Aurora Notifier to see the current and forecast status of the Northern Lights.
Open the Meteor Shower Calendar to see current and upcoming meteor showers.
Open the Time-and-Date website to see current and upcoming eclipses in your area.
Upcoming satellite passes including the International Space Station (ISS):
Upcoming satellite passes of the International Space Station (ISS):
Upcoming satellite passes of Iridium flares:
Swipe left or right to select a location.
You are about to delete this location. \nYou won\'t be able to recover it once it\'s gone. \nAre you sure?

Open the Variable Stars app to see details of some variable stars or open SkEye to see where they would be in the sky.\n\nVariable Stars and SkEye are apps by other authors who are respectively responsible for the content.
Select a planet to view in SkEye as it would look right now.
Select a conjunction to view in SkEye as it would look right now.
Select a star to view in SkEye as it would look right now.
Select a constellation to view in SkEye as it would look right now.
